awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Reserach:Active Societal Participation in Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Active Societal Participation In Research and Education (ASPIRE) aims to cultivate a generation of geoscientists with the leadership knowledge and skills, scholarship, and material support to communicate the social relevance of geosciences, and thereby, to broaden participation in these fields. The proposed project will evaluate the effectiveness of place-based science as a vehicle for increasing diversity in the Geoscience. The ASPIRE collaborators will organize Mobile Working Groups (MWG) that will be led by an academic geoscientist who works with a local community on issues that require an expertise in the geosciences. These MWG leaders are referred to as "gate-openers". Each MWG will focus on a single issue linked to a single community, but ASPIRE will support multiple MWGs working across a variety of issues and geoscience topics. 

During the pilot period, ASPIRE will: 1) learn from the experiences and qualities of geoscientists who already possess experience leading community-relevant research, 2) support them "individually and collectively" as leaders of MWGs over a period of one year, 3) identify from their prior and current experiences the sort of leadership required to bridge underserved and geoscience communities, and 4) define and refine the leadership, networking, and logistical support needs that a fully implemented "bricks and mortar" center would require. Over the course of the pilot project, ASPIRE will conservatively involve up to forty individuals from across a variety of geoscience institutions, with an additional thirty or more participants, support staff and evaluators. The PIs hypothesize that in institutionalizing a new mode of geoscience research (MWG), learning from the leaders' experiences with MWG, and refining a leadership development program based on findings, they will have a scalable leadership tool and organizational structure that will rebrand the geosciences as socially relevant and inclusive of geoscientists from diverse backgrounds.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT:
Active Societal Participation In Research and Education (ASPIRE) 


Community-based research models hold potential to change the relevance of the geosciences to the public and who conducts geoscience research. It may also begin to redress historical injustices engrained in geosciences’ extractive activities and ways of knowing. However, this potential depends on such projects being led in ways that meaningfully and equitably bridge the worlds of scientists and those of community stakeholders. Active Societal Participation In Research and Education (ASPIRE) strives to refine our understanding of equitable leadership in community-based research contexts. 

A primary outcome of ASPIRE has been to sponsor six research projects that bring together academics, community members, and other professionals in collaboration on community-identified problems. The model moves research off campus and into the community, and out of the boundaries of typical scientific investigation into more broadly defined problems that often include socio-political dynamics of scientific topics. These problems are place-specific; for example, one ASPIRE project studied how urbanization in Honolulu threatened water volume on a family watercress farm just outside of the city. Another project examined how development along the Los Angeles River threatens water quality. These projects benefit from the wisdom of local community members, and communities are better positioned to advocate for their needs with scientific data the projects collect. All ASPIRE projects have been led by a geoscientist who has one foot in higher education and the other in the community – a role that we call the boundary spanner. PI Corey Garza at California-State Monterey Bay led this aspect of the project.

A second outcome of the pilot award was to host a two day workshop bringing together some of the best minds in place-based, community-based geoscience, to refine the approach that ASPIRE would advocate. Through this workshop, we collaboratively developed “equitable exchange,” as a principled model for the co-production of knowledge. It emphasizes that “currencies” (defined as the rewards and value from participating in research), may differ between local communities and geoscientists. When these currencies are recognized and respectfully exchanged, it provides a place-based way to bridge basic and applied science as well as academic and local communities. Co-PI Julia Parrish coordinated this workshop, and Co-PI Lora Harris led eighteen participants in the workshop in publishing a peer-reviewed paper that outlines this framework. 

A third outcome, in direct support of the Geoscience Opportunities in Leadership for Diversity (GOLD) program, has been research about what boundary-spanning leadership practices contribute to an equitable exchange of knowledge between scientists and community members. Through methods of comparative case study using the ASPIRE supported projects, we identify leadership practices that facilitate successful place-based, community-based research involving scientists and members of underrepresented communities. We find boundary-spanning leadership to include a critical awareness of scientific history, efforts to center community at all phases of the work, and four practices that build trust. This research was led by Co-PI Julie Posselt and doctoral candidate Deborah Southern, and is currently under peer review.

A fourth outcome has been to carry out a six part webinar series that was collaboratively developed by the ASPIRE PI’s (with leadership from Co-PI Lora Harris), graduate students at University of Maryland and University of Southern California, leaders of American Geophysical Union’s Thriving Earth Exchange, and experts, practitioners, and community advisors. The series explored community engagement and leadership as means of broadening participation in the geosciences. Each of the webinar topics was oriented around a major finding of the research described above. The sessions used an equity lens to consider how connecting academic and federal agency geoscientists with underserved communities can contribute to social and environmental justice. A google site provided participants access to relevant curriculum and supplemental literature. Each webinar included brief presentations about the main topic, followed by extended discussion in small and large groups, and time for community members to share observations. It fostered reflection, discussion, and working relationships that will advance the mission of ASPIRE after the pilot award is complete.
